repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Consolidation of the Protected
            Areas System Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings of the Consolidation of the
            Protected Areas System Project for Mexico were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; the risk to the development
            outcome was moderate; the Bank's performance was
            satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance was
            satisfactory as well. There were numerous lessons learned on
            this project. On project design and the grant instrument:
            providing flexibility during implementation to adjust design
            to emerging realities within broad objectives allows
            opportunities for maximizing project impact. On the
            endowment and institutional arrangements: public private
            partnerships can provide an effective, mutually beneficial
            vehicle that capitalizes on the best that each of the
            partners have to provide. On impacts/outcomes: it is
            possible to measure habitat transformation, but results will
            likely only be measurable if measured annually, over time.
            More work needs to be done on establishing strategies for
            measuring species populations. On Protected Area (PA)
            management with social responsibility: Protected Area
            Councils are an important tool for developing the culture of
            conservation and for stakeholder participation. On
            sustainable activities and community relations in PAs:
            projects are most successful when: a) they require
            counterpart funding from the implementing organization; b)
            focus on critical management issues; c) well functioning
            projects are extended over a number of years; and d) there
            is strong interaction between the PA management team and the
            implementing organization. On monitoring of biodiversity and
            habitat loss indicators: species population surveys need to
            be more closely organized with PA Directors to help improve
            their relevance for PA management strategies.

docna.cdata!:
Mexico - Consolidation of the Protected
            Areas System Project

15356926.trustfund:
BBGEF-BB GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL FUND,TF021812-BNPP-ENVIRONMENT :
            ENVIRONMENTAL & SOCIOECONOMIC IMPACT STUDY,TF023379-GEF2 : MEXICO CONSOLIDATION OF
            THE PROTECTED AREAS PROGRAM (SINAP II),TF038474-MEXICO:  CONSOLIDATION OF
            PROTECTED AREAS,TF040017-MEXICO - PROTECTED AREAS,TF050311-GEF2-MEXICO:CONSOLIDATION OF
            THE PROTECTED AREAS SYSTEM PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Consolidation of the Protected
            Areas System Project : supplemental GEF grant

abstracts.cdata!:
The Consolidation of the Protected Areas
            System Project's objective is to promote the
            conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity in Mexico
            through the consolidation of the National Protected Areas
            System (SINAP) by: (a) conserving globally important
            biodiversity in selected protected areas (PA) of SINAP
            through an endowment fund; (b) promoting the economic,
            social and environmental sustainability of productive
            activities in selected PAS; (c) promoting social
            co-responsibility for conservation; and (d) in general,
            promoting the inclusion of biodiversity conservation and
            sustainable criteria in development projects and other
            practices affecting selected PAs. This project extends the
            PA program initiated with global environmental facility
            (GEF) funding in 1992 and restructured as an endowment fund
            for 10 PAS in 1997 (Project SNAP I), by adding 12 new PAS to
            the program. There have been no substantial changes to the
            project's original objectives and design since Board approval.

            ENVIRONMENTAL & SOCIOECONOMIC IMPACT STUDY,TF023379-GEF2 : MEXICO CONSOLIDATION OF

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Additional Financing for
            Consolidation of the Protected Areas System Project : Fourth Tranche

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's global objective is
            to promote the conservation and sustainable use of
            biodiversity in Mexico through the consolidation of the
            National System of Protected Areas (SINAP). Project
            development objectives are: 1) to conserve globally
            important biodiversity in selected areas of SINAP; 2) to
            promote the economic, social and environmental
            sustainability of productive activities in selected
            protected areas; 3) to promote social co-responsibility for
            conservation; 4) and to promote the inclusion of
            biodiversity conservation and sustainable use criteria in
            development projects. It is intended to carry out actions
            related to education, agricultural diversification of
            production and manufacturing, artistic and sporting
            activities aimed at school-age population, women, seniors
            and groups of producers organized in conditions of
            vulnerability or belonging to indigenous groups. The
            approach of the project towards indigenous groups fully
            respects the Mexican legal framework protecting their
            rights. An indigenous peoples strategy has been prepared to
            ensure that indigenous communities participate and benefit
            from the project. The project is not expected to have any
            negative impact on indigenous population. The present plan
            is intended to address the agricultural socio-cultural
            reality in all its diversity to ensure that indigenous and
            vulnerable groups become feasible actors and subjects in the
            medium term transformation and who will improve their living
            conditions, under a framework of sustainability. The project
            will contribute to improving the living conditions of
            indigenous people who experience very high poverty in the
            Reserve, in terms of economic, social, health, environmental
            and cultural areas.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Consolidation of the Protected
            Areas System Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The consolidation of the protected areas
            system project for Mexico will promote the conservation and
            sustainable use of biodiversity in Mexico through the
            consolidation of the National System Protected Areas (SNAP)
            by: conserving globally important biodiversity in selected
            areas of SNAP through an endowment fund; promoting the
            economic, social and environmental sustainability of
            productive activities in selected protected areas; promoting
            social co-responsibility for conservation; and in general,
            promoting the inclusion of biodiversity conservation and
            sustainable criteria in development projects and other
            practices affecting selected protected areas. This project
            extends the protected areas program initiated with GEF
            funding in 1992 and restructured as an endowment funds to
            support conservation of 10 protected areas in 1997 (Project
            SINAP l),by adding 12 new protected areas to the program.
